active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, share a real-world or hypothetical cybersecurity incident where intuition led to poor decisions (e.g., confirmation bias in threat detection). How could structured critical thinking (analysis, evaluation) have improved team response? Reference NIST SP 800-61 Rev 2 phases.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Critical Thinking within Incident Response Team Organization (Non-Technical Skills). Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 002_Incident Response And Forensics > 002_Incident Response Team Organization > 009_Skills and Training > Non-Technical Skills > Critical Thinking. Use NIST SP 800-61 Rev 2 (2012) accurately: Phases - Preparation, Detection & Analysis, Containment/Eradication/Recovery, Post-Incident. Correct myths: No Rev 3 exists yet. Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [insert full list above] - Active Learning: Inspire flashcards that prep for discussions/activities (e.g., scenario Qs). - Scaffolding: Distribute cards across 4 layers [insert summaries]. - Concept Map: Critical Thinking central, branches to IR phases/forensics/NIST CSF. - Misconceptions: Distractors for intuition vs. CT, biases. - Sources: NIST (https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-61r2.pdf), Paul-Elder (https://www.criticalthinking.org/pages/defining-critical-thinking/766). Generate 25 flashcards in JSON array: [{'front': '...', 'back': {'answer': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'distractors': [...], 'references': '...'}}, ...]. Follow schema exactly. Ensure university-level pedagogy: active recall, spaced repetition, higher-order thinking. Cover all Bloom's levels progressively.
